[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Michigan VII DUAP document defines requirements to manage vehicle infrastructure integration, ensuring efficient traffic flow, safety, and optimized decision-making through real-time data processing.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: Michigan VII DUAP facilitates real-time traffic data collection, monitoring, and communication, enabling advanced traffic management strategies such as signal optimization and incident response to improve safety and reduce congestion.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: Michigan VII DUAP connects with traffic controllers, sensors, and transportation databases.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: Michigan VII DUAP provides a web dashboard for managing traffic data.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: Michigan VII DUAP runs on servers supporting Intel Core i5/AMD Ryzen 5 processors.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: Michigan VII DUAP interacts with SQL databases and GIS software.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: Michigan VII DUAP supports V2I communication using LTE protocols.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: Michigan VII DUAP is optimized for systems with 8GB RAM.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: Michigan VII DUAP handles traffic signals, incidents, and data collection.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: Michigan VII DUAP is customizable for road networks and urban setups.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: Michigan VII DUAP works with external traffic and reporting systems.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: Michigan VII DUAP manages traffic data, signal adjustments, and incident reporting.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: Michigan VII DUAP is designed for traffic managers, planners, and system administrators.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: Michigan VII DUAP relies on stable communication networks and hardware compatibility.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: Michigan VII DUAP requires V2I-enabled vehicles and infrastructure.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Traffic Signal Coordination: Adjusting traffic signals for smoother flow.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall connect to traffic controllers for real-time coordination.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall provide APIs for accessing traffic data.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall adjust signals based on live conditions (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall generate traffic reports (REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The dashboard shall offer user-friendly navigation and visualization tools.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process data within 2 seconds.
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall support 1,000 concurrent connections.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store traffic data for 5 years.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall enable data export in standard formats.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall follow modular design principles.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with USDOT ITS standards.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-002: The system shall provide feedback within 1 second for user actions.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Tests validate real-time processing, signal coordination, and system reliability.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, and setup guides.
[SEC] 5. References: VII DUAP Technical Manual, USDOT ITS Standards, and GIS Guide.
